subject: Re: [junit] Constructor called multiple times?
msgSnippet: ... a) Not all of my state is read-only.  What doesvTestNG do to prevent me from making mistakes when using mutable state? b) I have occasionally made mistakes
messageBody:
On 4/3/07, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> On 03 Apr 2007 16:05:52 -0700, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> > 2b) If your tests are not cheap to initialize and run because they're
> > actually integration tests, acceptance tests, or end-to-end system
> tests,
> > then you might want state to persist, trading off safety for
> performance.
>
> I don't understand how maintaining read-only state trades off safety?


a) Not all of my state is read-only. What doesvTestNG do to prevent me from
making mistakes when using mutable state?
b) I have occasionally made mistakes where immutable objects become
mutable. Stupid mistakes, to be sure, but that's why I write tests.


> > In JUnit 3.8, you can use TestSetup for this state, and in JUnit 4, you
> can
> > use @BeforeClass with statics
>
> Statics are extremely problematic with integration tools (ant, maven
> or IDE's) and they are also inherently a lot less thread-safe,
> therefore preventing you from leveraging parallelism.


I've written tests that use static state and work fine from ant, but I don't
know everything. Can you fill me in?


> > or you can search Google for "JUnit
> > OneInstance.class", which will give you a solution allowing you to only
> > instantiate your test class once.
>
> Similary, I have always found JUnit tests hard to run reliably when
> they start depending on specialized runners. Do the Eclipse and IDEA
> plug-ins support @RunWith?


Eclipse: Yes, natively.
IDEA: I believe there was a bug a while back. I've put it on my todo list
to try it out on the latest public beta (assuming there is one), but if
someone has already tried it, I'd love to know.

Just to be clear, JUnit 4 can replicate both "one instance for all tests"
and "one instance for each test" behavior in a way that works seamlessly
with, I know, ant and Eclipse, and will eventually be possible, when bugs
are fixed, in other runners. Of course, each tool must be opinionated in
its defaults, but I assume that most tool users appreciate the final
decision being up to them. I'd ask about TestNG, but this is the JUnit
list. :-)

Anyway, I think the confusion of the original author is still
> justified: since both the constructor and setUp() are invoked before
> every test method, why have both?


I'll leave it up to the original author to say whether several good-faith
attempts to answer that exact question have failed.

David Saff
